lore: Robodomi can transfer a ton of information in seconds, but quantum engineering has given some cybernetic creatures abilities that go beyond that. Mechto represents the peak of this technology, capable of copying other synthetic creatures' unique abilities and transferring them to any other being it comes into contact with.
menagerieDialog: (It's powered down, occasional beeps and whirs emanating from its chassis.)

My processors can calculate a million strategies per second. How may I assist you?

lore: Sometimes, Robodomi that break down beyond repair can't be fixed with traditional methods, and their remains could cause serious environmental harm. That's why abandonment is heavily penalized.\n\nZyphra's core has magical properties that make its battery practically endless as long as it's in motion. The catch is that it absorbs all the kinetic energy it produces, which keeps it from being able to cause physical harm by touching others.

lore: Zeuschunds are forest dogs from Undolim, trained by humans much like wolves were. They became loyal partners, working hand-in-paw with their human friends on many tasks. Unlike wolves, these dogs have orc-like strength, making them fierce allies in the hunt and on the battlefield. But their true power shows after deathâ€”if they've bonded deeply with their friends, a sudden heartbeat brings them back. Fueled by raw energy, they rise again, unstoppable and capable of crushing foes that seemed unbeatable.

lore: Caliban, now able to manifest in the physical world, has created Balcanâ€”his emissary. Balcan is a creature of great intelligence and grace, adept at navigating both the refined circles of the elite and the bustling streets of the common folk. His mission is to spread word of his master's greatness and rally followers, with the hope that their belief will bring Caliban back to life, ready to crush the other gods once and for all.

Created from part of Hydranox's power, Xandor serves as a steward to this corrupted force, but it will not hesitate to kill anyone who dares approach its lair.

Gorpin serves his master unconditionally, doing whatever is necessary, though his main tasks involve cleaning his lair and cooking extravagant meals that could rival any top-tier chef.

lore: Trion and Jotun were once rivals, but through the centuries, they became the best of friends. Trapped together on a mysterious magical island, they battled endlessly, each match ending in a stalemate. Despite their fierce rivalry, every fight was followed by a celebration and a peaceful night side by side. That is, until a band of ruthless smugglers interfered, leading to Trion's defeat and the theft of his treasure. Though this wasn't Trion's intention, Jotun absorbed much of his power. Furious, the two joined forces to take down the intruders and escape the island, seeking a new path together.

lore: "Maybe Miredol is the only maniac capable of staying still for a while," said the scientist in charge of the experiment. "Ah, really?" asked his colleague, curious. "How did you catch him then?" she continued. "Well, he was just sitting there," the scientist responded. "I had the interns bring him in." Miredol, eerily still, then began to laughâ€”a chilling, maniacal laughter that foreshadowed bloodshed. The colleague, terrified, stared wide-eyed, then turned and bolted, screaming, "Run while you still can!"

Before gaining too much mass, they can soar through the air with ease, hunting from both above and below.

lore: "Bow before me, for I am the prodigal son, the prince of dragons!" This is Darboen's signature line whenever he meets a noble. He uses it to intimidate and get what he wants, but the most common response is an arched eyebrow. If he's met with mockery, Darboen will unleash fire or some other element from his tiny jaws and storm off, vowing revenge. Little do these highborn know, he'll return one dayâ€”accompanied by none other than the King of Dragons himself.

lore: The Nether Orb that once controlled Saint Althea became sentient after her defeat, forming its own body and mind. Nalesath is a mysterious figure who weaves in and out of the upper echelons of society, always speaking with calculated caution to avoid drawing too much attention. It has cultivated a network of powerful allies in Rodia, exchanging favors for information. Its true motives remain unclear, but its influence continues to grow.

lore: A Godspawn of The Ancestor, Rastoc thrives on combat, seeking out opponents who can challenge him. He has delved deeply into Rodian history, especially the war against the Sphinxes, and has fought in countless conflictsâ€”though his true location when not in battle is a mystery. Rastoc has no patience for arrogance or cowardice, and he's always ready to lend his strength to a righteous cause.

lore: Life for Underdwellers once centered on hunting and gathering. Today, information is their most prized possession, and they've earned a reputation as the most discreet traders of secrets.\n\nUnderdweller Rot-Thieves don't just kill silentlyâ€”they can brand their victims with a mark that makes resurrection impossible.
menagerieDialog: (It's huddled in a dark corner, seemingly more comfortable there.)
The surface dwellers will learn to fear the depths!
In the darkness, one learns to see truths others miss. Shall I enlighten you?
The pressure of the deep has made me unbreakable!
(It's darting about erratically, as if unused to open spaces.)
name: Underdweller Rot-thief

lore: Underdwellers come from swampy lands, but as cities grew, they adapted to living on the fringes of society.\n\nUnderdweller Hexblades are experts at finding enemy weaknessesâ€”be it a limp or a blind spotâ€”and use those flaws to their advantage or teach others how to.

lore: When shady business needs doing, many turn to the Underdwellersâ€”silent, efficient, and always fair in their dealings. They slip in, slip out, and leave no trace but a satisfied client. But not every plan works out. That's where the Underdweller Mischiefmaker comes in. These tight-lipped tacticians thrive in chaos, always ready with backup plans and silent retreats. If something goes wrong, they don't panicâ€”they vanish, dragging their team to safety before fading into the dark themselves.

lore: No one knows the city's underground like the Underdwellers. Moving through the darkness is always quicker and safer, and the Underdweller Ripper uses this to stalk victims by their footsteps above. When the target turns into a quiet alley, the ripper emerges, knife ready to end the hunt.
menagerieDialog: (It's huddled in a dark corner, seemingly more comfortable there.)

lore: Underdwellers thrive in the shadows, especially when the job requires discretion. For them, staying unknown is a mark of pride, and no Underdweller worth their salt lets their name circulate where it shouldn't.\n\nUnderdweller Ritesmasters are the veterans of their kind, entrusted with revealing the secrets of the modern world to their younger kin. No Underdweller Ritesmaster is ever blessed by their people unless they've proven themselvesâ€”usually through acts of larceny, coercion, or the handling of contraband.

(It's darting about erratically, as if unused to open spaces.)
name: Underdweller Ritesmaster

lore: Underdwellers weren't expected to become the allies everyone relies on in the city's shadows. They possess natural caution and a sharp business sense, despite having stayed hidden for thousands of years in their small swamp villages.\n\nUnderdweller Fearmongers rarely act directly, preferring to intimidateâ€”using threats and violent gestures behind closed doors to make sure their targets give in.
menagerieDialog: (It's huddled in a dark corner, seemingly more comfortable there.)
The surface dwellers will learn to fear the depths!
In the darkness, one learns to see truths others miss. Shall I enlighten you?
The pressure of the deep has made me unbreakable!
(It's darting about erratically, as if unused to open spaces.)
name: Underdweller Fearmonger

lore: Crafting a Cataclysm requires sacrificing multiple spell gems, and the element of those gems determines what kind of creature it creates.\n\nThe Sky Cataclysm is made of fierce winds that can send small creatures and objects flying. While they lack a mind of their own, they seem to be more restless when strong winds blow.
menagerieDialog: (It's calm for once, gently pulsing with ethereal energy.)
I am the storm that ends worlds. Point me at our foes!
The secrets of the universe flow through me. What would you like to know?
The elements themselves bend to my will. No force can harm me!
(It's swirling violently, barely contained within its form.)
name: Sky Cataclysm

lore: The process of creating a cataclysm is life-threatening, and that's why criminal syndicates force people to work on them.\n\nThe Volcanic Cataclysm gives off an intense heat that can melt snow in seconds. In one instance, it burned down an entire neighborhood in a village in Neralim from the constant spells it cast.
menagerieDialog: (It's calm for once, gently pulsing with ethereal energy.)
I am the storm that ends worlds. Point me at our foes!
The secrets of the universe flow through me. What would you like to know?
The elements themselves bend to my will. No force can harm me!
(It's swirling violently, barely contained within its form.)
name: Volcanic Cataclysm

lore: Making a Cataclysm is riskyâ€”sometimes it results in the lab blowing up.\n\nThe Oceanic Cataclysm spins a whirlpool at insane speeds. Anyone who touches it risks being sucked in and drowned by its overwhelming force.
menagerieDialog: (It's calm for once, gently pulsing with ethereal energy.)
I am the storm that ends worlds. Point me at our foes!
The secrets of the universe flow through me. What would you like to know?
The elements themselves bend to my will. No force can harm me!
(It's swirling violently, barely contained within its form.)
name: Oceanic Cataclysm

lore: Cataclysms are a hot commodity in the black market, which is why authorities in Siralim and other nations created a device that detects them within a 100-meter range.\n\nThe Storm Cataclysm makes a deafening roar before appearing. Inside it, lightning and thunder rage, and it can kill a large animal within seconds of contact.
menagerieDialog: (It's calm for once, gently pulsing with ethereal energy.)
I am the storm that ends worlds. Point me at our foes!
The secrets of the universe flow through me. What would you like to know?
The elements themselves bend to my will. No force can harm me!
(It's swirling violently, barely contained within its form.)
name: Storm Cataclysm

lore: To create a Cataclysm, magic has to be focused intensely for days.\n\nThe Terra Cataclysm is occasionally used for travel, but those lacking common sense quickly realize that it's a dangerous practice. It moves quickly up and down, crashing into the ground repeatedly.
menagerieDialog: (It's calm for once, gently pulsing with ethereal energy.)
I am the storm that ends worlds. Point me at our foes!
The secrets of the universe flow through me. What would you like to know?
The elements themselves bend to my will. No force can harm me!
(It's swirling violently, barely contained within its form.)
name: Terra Cataclysm

lore: Cataclysms are creatures created in secret, illegal labs.\n\nThe Glacial Cataclysm unleashes a bone-chilling cold that can freeze water in mere minutes. Sometimes, shady groups use it for torture, though the creature cannot help but cast its spell, and usually ends up killing the victims instead.
menagerieDialog: (It's calm for once, gently pulsing with ethereal energy.)
I am the storm that ends worlds. Point me at our foes!
The secrets of the universe flow through me. What would you like to know?
The elements themselves bend to my will. No force can harm me!
(It's swirling violently, barely contained within its form.)
name: Glacial Cataclysm

lore: Cataclysms are highly unstable magical creations that constantly leak dangerous spells. They should only be removed from their container when used in combat.\n\nBeing near a Pandemic Cataclysm without proper protection can cause serious illness due to the viruses it carries. One time, a city in Siralim went into quarantine because of one.
menagerieDialog: (It's calm for once, gently pulsing with ethereal energy.)
I am the storm that ends worlds. Point me at our foes!
The secrets of the universe flow through me. What would you like to know?
The elements themselves bend to my will. No force can harm me!
(It's swirling violently, barely contained within its form.)
name: Pandemic Cataclysm

lore: Many nations, including Siralim, have harsh laws against creating Cataclysms.\n\nThe destruction caused by the Explosive Cataclysm is similar to its counterpartsâ€”everything nearby explodes. Extreme caution is advised.
menagerieDialog: (It's calm for once, gently pulsing with ethereal energy.)
I am the storm that ends worlds. Point me at our foes!
The secrets of the universe flow through me. What would you like to know?
The elements themselves bend to my will. No force can harm me!
(It's swirling violently, barely contained within its form.)
name: Explosive Cataclysm

lore: Though cataclysms are human-sized, they can be stored in containers, as long as they stay sealed.\n\nThe Almighty Cataclysm leaves destruction and chaos in its wake. Its explosions make it impossible to travel with safely, which is why it must always be kept sealed away.
menagerieDialog: (It's calm for once, gently pulsing with ethereal energy.)
I am the storm that ends worlds. Point me at our foes!
The secrets of the universe flow through me. What would you like to know?
The elements themselves bend to my will. No force can harm me!
(It's swirling violently, barely contained within its form.)
name: Almighty Cataclysm

lore: If a Cataclysm is left in storage too long, it will inevitably burst its container, causing a dangerous explosion.\n\nThe explosions of a Nuclear Cataclysm leave behind deadly radiation that can kill anyone who gets too close or stays for too long. Once, a mafia boss in Andolin released one near the mayor's house in a big city, and although it was contained quickly, the damage was done, and the area had to be decontaminated.
menagerieDialog: (It's calm for once, gently pulsing with ethereal energy.)
I am the storm that ends worlds. Point me at our foes!
The secrets of the universe flow through me. What would you like to know?
The elements themselves bend to my will. No force can harm me!
(It's swirling violently, barely contained within its form.)
name: Nuclear Cataclysm

lore: Some Cataclysms are used for assassination, hidden among the victim's belongings before they explode.\n\nThe Cosmic Cataclysm can create black holes that suck in everything around it, causing massive destruction. Any insect that touches it is instantly crushed by its immense gravity.
menagerieDialog: (It's calm for once, gently pulsing with ethereal energy.)
I am the storm that ends worlds. Point me at our foes!
The secrets of the universe flow through me. What would you like to know?
The elements themselves bend to my will. No force can harm me!
(It's swirling violently, barely contained within its form.)
name: Cosmic Cataclysm

lore: Torture devices have long held a notorious reputation, used across countless generations all over the world. But as times changed, some nations officially outlawed their useâ€”at least on paper. This, of course, left behind a massive stockpile of now-obsolete instruments like the Iron Maiden. Rather than destroy them, places like Rodia decided to enchant them and put them to use: fighting on the front lines or patrolling rough neighborhoods to scare criminals into behaving.
menagerieDialog: I do not wish to speak to you right now. I would prefer to return to where I came from.
You would dare to rip me from my portal and summon me to this dying world? You have no shame.
I am bound to serve you, but know that it is not by choice.
I do not belong here in your filthy Menagerie. I deserve my own quarters in your castle!
Give me freedom, or give me death!
name: Iron Maiden

lore: The fiercest of the Mirelings, the Mireling Striker wields thick, veiny muscles to strike with deadly precision and bone-crushing force. It picks up every language it encounters, making it the go-to for dealing with other species. Its training begins at birth and ends only when its fists can punch through stone without a scratch.
menagerieDialog: (They're huddled together in a small pool, occasionally blowing bubbles.)
We may be small, but our fury is mighty! To battle!
The secrets of the swamp are ours. Care to learn some ancient wisdom?
Our swamp magic protects us! You'll never break through!
(They're hopping about frantically, croaking war cries.)
name: Mireling Striker

lore: Deep in the rotting swamps where neither light nor sound dare trespass, the Mireling Corruptor grows parasitic fungi from its own flesh. Its empty gaze and perpetual grin stand in stark contrast to the crude skull of hardened sludge it always carries. It taints the earth it walks on, leaving poisonous fungal gardens blooming in its wake. Some say it isn't a living creature at all, but a spirit that seeks only to keep its habitat undisturbed.
menagerieDialog: (They're huddled together in a small pool, occasionally blowing bubbles.)
We may be small, but our fury is mighty! To battle!
The secrets of the swamp are ours. Care to learn some ancient wisdom?
Our swamp magic protects us! You'll never break through!
(They're hopping about frantically, croaking war cries.)
name: Mireling Corruptor

lore: At night in the swamp gatherings where Mirelings croak together, the Mireling Arbitrator acts as judge, executioner, and spectacle all in one. Its word holds unquestionable power: whatever it declares true becomes reality, even if the reasons aren't clear. Few dare contradict it, and none do so twice. Some of them abandon their tribe and become solitary creatures wandering the swamps, living peaceful and quiet lives.
menagerieDialog: (They're huddled together in a small pool, occasionally blowing bubbles.)
We may be small, but our fury is mighty! To battle!
The secrets of the swamp are ours. Care to learn some ancient wisdom?
Our swamp magic protects us! You'll never break through!
(They're hopping about frantically, croaking war cries.)
name: Mireling Arbitrator

lore: Agile and deadly, the Mireling Dart-Frog blends into the foliage until it's far too late. It can launch crystallized spines coated in neuroparalytic venom from its webbed fingers, and it climbs any surface to strike from a safer, more surprising vantage point. Some lizardfolk tribes see them as guardian spiritsâ€”though they still keep their distance, treating them more like a curse than a blessing.
menagerieDialog: (They're huddled together in a small pool, occasionally blowing bubbles.)
We may be small, but our fury is mighty! To battle!
The secrets of the swamp are ours. Care to learn some ancient wisdom?
Our swamp magic protects us! You'll never break through!
(They're hopping about frantically, croaking war cries.)
name: Mireling Dart Frog

lore: Wise among the Mirelings, the Mireling Spellscatterer wears robes made of bark and lichens and carries a staff carved with symbols representing the lunar cycles. It can corrupt enemy spells and return them altered, like a distorted reflection in a murky pond. Notably, it can disrupt magical concealment spells so those using them become fully visible to its kind. In groups, they can turn powerful magical barriers into deadly traps for those trapped inside.
menagerieDialog: (They're huddled together in a small pool, occasionally blowing bubbles.)
We may be small, but our fury is mighty! To battle!
The secrets of the swamp are ours. Care to learn some ancient wisdom?
Our swamp magic protects us! You'll never break through!
(They're hopping about frantically, croaking war cries.)
name: Mireling Spellscatterer

lore: Whether mutation or god, the Kaleidotoad is a chromatic rarityâ€”an unstable genetic mix born from some ancient arcane experiment by the Mireling Spellscatterers. Its colors shift with its mood, and its hypnotic gaze can unsettle even the steadiest soul. Some follow it like a prophet, while others hunt it out of superstition. The former often end up slaves to its whims, and the latter usually meet the same fate.
menagerieDialog: (They're huddled together in a small pool, occasionally blowing bubbles.)
We may be small, but our fury is mighty! To battle!
The secrets of the swamp are ours. Care to learn some ancient wisdom?
Our swamp magic protects us! You'll never break through!
(They're hopping about frantically, croaking war cries.)
name: Kaleido-toad

lore: This burger has the annoying habit of staying put in the middle of the road, waiting for someone to come close enough to try and eat it. As soon as someone gets too close, it'll spring into action and attempt to devour them instead. Unfortunately for Wacky Burger, this trick is old, and no one in their right mind would trust a giant burger just sitting there on its own. Caravans typically go around them or have their guards take action when they spot one.
menagerieDialog: I do not wish to speak to you right now. I would prefer to return to where I came from.
You would dare to rip me from my portal and summon me to this dying world? You have no shame.
I am bound to serve you, but know that it is not by choice.
I do not belong here in your filthy Menagerie. I deserve my own quarters in your castle!
Give me freedom, or give me death!
name: Wacky Burger

lore: These eggs were infected by a malicious spirit that ruined what should have been a delicious meal. Eating the green substance that leaks from their shells results in immediate possession, leading to uncontrollable homicidal behavior. Some criminal organizations use these to dispose of unwanted subordinates, forcing them to eat the eggs in crowded places, taking out both the target and those around them.

lore: These malicious spirits haunt the night, seeking out victims to kill in brutal, savage ways. Their knife is rumored to be cursed, though in reality, it's more of a multi-purpose weapon. Once they wound someone with it, the Ripper can track them down, no matter how far they run or how much time has passed.

lore: Many of these creatures work as guides for travelers in dense forests. However, there have been cases where some used their services as a trap. Once deep in the woods with their clients, they turned on them, making them their victims. That's why, today, any guide must be accredited by the Rodian government to guarantee the safety of their journey.

lore: This bed is cursed, ensuring that anyone who lies on it will be plagued by terrifying nightmares. At first glance, it might seem like a normal bed, able to disguise its true form. But if someone falls asleep on it, they'll be trapped in a nightmare that brings their deepest fears to life, and they'll never wake up on their own.

lore: It doesn't take much to realize that eating this mushroom could lead to serious health issues. In fact, one of the deadliest poisons in existence comes from these creatures, and when synthesized, it can cause devastating effects in a matter of seconds. Interestingly, the magical properties of this creature make its venom effective even against golems or spiritsâ€”beings that aren't traditionally considered alive.

lore: The origin of this creature is a complete mystery. The first one appeared suddenly in a crowded street in Siralim, and it stayed there, completely still, until the authorities took it away. When the Rodian government allowed further study, it was discovered that the creature was an empty shellâ€”nothing inside. Since then, more have appeared across the continent, with no one understanding how or why. A simple spell is all it takes to control them like puppets.

lore: This playful snake can be found in many different environments. It's one of the largest reptiles known, but it doesn't pose much of a threat to travelers or other creatures, as it feeds only on its own tail. Without this self-sustaining cycle, it would grow uncontrollably, struggle to move, and eventually die due to its inability to produce enough blood to sustain its size. Fortunately, its bite cauterizes any wound it causes, and its tail has no nerves, so it doesn't feel pain.

lore: This animated puppet was created with one goal in mind: murder. All it takes is placing a strand of hair, a nail, or any small part of the victim's body on its face. From that moment, Dollface knows exactly where to find them and begins its hunt, carrying out the only purpose it was created for; ending their life.

lore: It's easy to assume that Frosty Freezy is a creature of snow and ice, but in reality, it can often be found lounging on a beach, enjoying a cold treat. Its body naturally emits an intense cold, and not only does it thrive in the heat, but it actually enjoys it. However, if it gets exposed to too much cold, it starts to hallucinate and eventually freezes solid until someone comes to its aid.

lore: This creature is always the first to arrive at a party and is eager to have fun. It naturally emits helium, so it can inflate a floating balloon with just a little effort. If someone stays too close, they'll find their voice becoming higher-pitchedâ€”perfect for some laughs!

lore: This strange creature resides within a mysterious brew and controls a human-shaped puppet through magic. It can speak and blend in as an ordinary person when it chooses to. In fact, many of them live peacefully in various Rodian cities, working in fields like scientific research, pharmaceuticals, or herbalism.

lore: When magical creatures die and aren't consumed by others, their bodies start to decompose. However, sometimes these remains begin to move across the ground or water, drawn together by a strange magnetism. When they gather in large enough numbers, they come to life, forming a terrifying creature that devours anything magical in its path.

lore: Sir Roquefort, also known as the Count of Roquefort, was once a noble whose lands were overrun by an evil sorcerer and his army. Sir Roquefort fought valiantly, winning the battle before Siralim's reinforcements could arrive. However, on his deathbed, the sorcerer used all his dark power to transform Sir Roquefort into... well, Sir Roquefort. He remains a brave knight skilled in combat, but now he must be careful not to stay in damp areas for too long, as it could lead to mold infestations.

lore: Rodia has very strict rules when it comes to waste management, especially when it involves magical materials. The Phenominal Possum is a perfect example of why these laws are so severe, with heavy penalties for violations. This creature is loud, stinks to high heaven, and, on top of that, loves to cause trouble.

lore: An ancient curse created malevolent spirits that rise during snowstorms on the winter solstice. Legends say that hunting them for their carrot noses grants powers, though the carrot itself holds no such magic. However, it does affect their behaviorâ€”because to regrow the carrot, they must feed on the ears, toes, and noses of other creatures.

lore: They say this terrifying animated mouth has a bottomless hunger. Some speculate it is because it lacks the organs needed to actually process what it eats. However, it clearly also lacks the organs that would regulate hunger in the first placeâ€”so most people just assume it doesn't need to eat at all and is simply a jerk.

lore: Sometimes, strange objects from distant places wash up on the shores of Rodia. A scientist from Vanelin managed to get his hands on one of these items and started experimenting with it. Though he never fully figured out how it originally worked, he infused it with magic to make it move again. And sure enough, it started moving. Now, the sorcerer is working on recreating his experiment to sell it on the black market.

lore: Everyone knows rotten fruit can be dangerous, but some pieces are deadly, and not just when eaten. Some trees in Rodia, due to past battles or nearby rituals, are infused with magic. When their fruit begins to rot, it absorbs this magic and comes to life. The result is a vicious, mobile creature that will attack anyone unlucky enough to cross its path.

lore: This hot dog with a serious attitude made his debut in the underground fighting rings of Neralim. "You wanna bite me, you jerk? You feel like taking a nibble?" he often taunts his opponents. "AHHHHH, I'LL SHOVE SPICE UP YOUR..." Well, let's just leave that to your imagination, but the truth is, his punches pack a serious stingâ€”literally.

lore: This creature was born straight from the nightmares of a noble's son who had an intense fear of clowns. The sorcerer behind its creation had a questionable reputation, but at least he achieved his goal... if you only consider what he was trying to do. The creature wasted no time in screaming and attacking the sorcerer, who disappeared without a trace. Now, the family who hired him is nowhere to be found.

lore: The Ferino Riverâ€”the longest in Rodiaâ€”starts in the northern kingdom of Vanelin, crosses Siralim's western border, and flows through the kingdom of Undolim before emptying into the great Crimson Ocean. Along its entire length live the Benthic Guardians, creatures strictly controlled by Rodia's laws. They fiercely protect the waters, destroying anyone who dares pollute them. The problem? These guardians see anything unusual in the river as "waste," making crossing their territory as dangerous as facing a bear's den.
menagerieDialog: (It's nestled comfortably in its shell, seemingly at peace.)
(It's furiously snapping its shell open and closed, ready for battle.)
Did you know that my kind can live for over 500 years? I've got stories that would make your head spin!
My shell is impenetrable. Bring on your worst, I say!
I'm not just a clam, I'm a clam with ambition! Let's go already!
name: Benthic Guardian

lore: Created as part of a doctoral project at Andolin's magic university, this creature was built to record events and the exact time they'd happenâ€”so it could warn when the moment was close. Now, Chronoshatter Wyrms are prized helpers, coordinating builders, fishing boats, and other workers so no one has to keep track of time themselves.

Give me freedom, or give me death!
name: Chronoshatter Wyrm

lore: These creatures live in the dry plateaus of Andolin, where they dig complex tunnels used as homes, hunting grounds, and defense. They're extremely violentâ€”crossing their territory is not recommended. Nowadays, every good map marks their zones as dangerous, and well-equipped groups often hunt them. Rodia's government is debating whether to try making peace with these fierce beasts before they vanish forever.
menagerieDialog: I do not wish to speak to you right now. I would prefer to return to where I came from.

Give me freedom, or give me death!
name: Slash Shifter

lore: This creature wasn't born, didn't die, and wasn't called forthâ€”it just showed up one morning by a nameless grave. Since then, it roams Rodia's oldest cemeteries, dragging chains it never wore. It only fights if stopped, and its enemies are hit with a deep, haunting nostalgia for lives they never had. When it leaves, it sometimes leaves behind withered flowers where its opponent fell.
menagerieDialog: I do not wish to speak to you right now. I would prefer to return to where I came from.
You would dare to rip me from my portal and summon me to this dying world? You have no shame.
I am bound to serve you, but know that it is not by choice.
I do not belong here in your filthy Menagerie. I deserve my own quarters in your castle!
Give me freedom, or give me death!
name: Gravebound Eidolon

lore: Most Elementasaur species don't form herds, but none ignore each other. When they meet, they recognize one another and often exchange some kind of gesture. Sometimes, they even fight over territory.\n\nThe Holyguanodon buries itself for days, decades, or even over a century, becoming indistinguishable from the surrounding rock. Its awakening is usually driven by hunger, though often it's triggered when an intelligent species tries to reshape the land to build settlements.
menagerieDialog: (It's lounging peacefully, occasionally snorting small puffs of elemental energy.)
RAWR! Time to show these puny creatures what real power looks like!
The wisdom of the ancients and the power of the elements are mine to command. What would you like to know?
My hide is infused with primal magic. Nothing can harm me!
(It's stomping around, leaving trails of elemental energy in its wake.)
name: Holyguanodon

lore: Of all the Elementasaurs, the Darknonychus is the most avoidedâ€”even by its own kind. Its body seems out of sync with space-time, constantly shifting and distorting, making it an extremely dangerous foe when it attacks. Strangely, small wildlife around it either thrives or withers in moments, with no clear pattern.
menagerieDialog: (It's lounging peacefully, occasionally snorting small puffs of elemental energy.)
RAWR! Time to show these puny creatures what real power looks like!
The wisdom of the ancients and the power of the elements are mine to command. What would you like to know?
My hide is infused with primal magic. Nothing can harm me!
(It's stomping around, leaving trails of elemental energy in its wake.)
name: Darknonychus

lore: Marionette Evangelists are among the oldest of their kind, programmed to deliver sermons with a stirring voice and grand gestures. They can preach for weeks in town squares, churches, funerals, or taverns without ever changing a word. What's eerie is that nobody recalls who wrote their speeches, and some parts come from texts that are impossible to find.
menagerieDialog: (It hangs limply, awaiting its next command.)
Pull my strings and watch me dance... a dance of death!
I may be controlled, but my mind is my own. Let me share my observations with you.
You can't hurt what isn't truly alive. I am invincible!
(It's jerking about wildly, its limbs flailing in all directions.)
name: Marionette Evangelist

lore: Draconic Strixes are nocturnal birds of prey that have absorbed the essence of Dragons through feeding on their corpses over generations. Their scales are harder than tempered steel, and their gaze terrifies even ghosts. They don't speak but communicate through shrieks that cause visions in those who hear them. They only attack when absolutely sure they won't get hurt.

lore: The head of this creature gives off a mysterious multicolored glow, often compared to a rainbow. It can absorb small sources of visible light and alter their color at will. When many Prismagicians gather in one place, they can darken a large area or emit powerful beams of light in any color to confuse enemies or put on a dazzling show. Some of them even work with theater companies, handling lighting and special effects.
menagerieDialog: I do not wish to speak to you right now. I would prefer to return to where I came from.

Give me freedom, or give me death!
name: Prismagician

lore: This creature began as a therapeutic device for people suffering from chronic nightmares. The bad dreams were meant to be channeled into these plush rabbitsâ€”but after a few months, they started to come alive. Haunted by the only memories they'd ever known, they began to lash out at anyone they encountered. It was later discovered that the bunnies had been sold without proper safety testing. Authorities are still searching for those responsible.
menagerieDialog: I do not wish to speak to you right now. I would prefer to return to where I came from.
You would dare to rip me from my portal and summon me to this dying world? You have no shame.

lore: With a distinguished bearing and impeccable manners, this abyssal dweller doesn't speak, but its gaze judges as if it has spent centuries in a God's court. It communicates with slow, deliberate gestures and never attacks without first straightening its hat. It is said that those defeated by this creature are condemned to eternal good manners.
menagerieDialog: (It clicks its jaws twice, then stares through you like a dying fish.)
(It gurgles softly, then slaps a wet limb against the wall in what you assume is a gesture of approval. Maybe.)
(You find it chewing on something unidentifiable. You hope it's not one of your other creatures.)
(It's dripping a strange fluid onto the floor. Your other creatures wisely keep their distance.)
(Its jaw unhinges briefly, revealing rows of teeth spiraling inward. You're not sure if itâ€™s yawning or threatening you.)
name: Elegant Denizen

lore: Legend says it was born from the echo of an ancient song, trapped inside a pearl for a thousand years. Its shimmering shell emits vibrations that alter the thoughts of those who hear them, erasing fears or awakening long-forgotten memories. On some islands, it is worshiped as the guardian of the secrets the sea chose not to return.
menagerieDialog: (It clicks its jaws twice, then stares through you like a dying fish.)
(It gurgles softly, then slaps a wet limb against the wall in what you assume is a gesture of approval. Maybe.)

lore: The Melodic Denizen glides through reefs, playing a sea harp with unmatched grace. Its melodies gently sway the currents, affect sea creatures, and stir the emotions of those who hear it. Sailors say its song can bring dead coral back to life... or shatter a heart in an instant.
menagerieDialog: (It clicks its jaws twice, then stares through you like a dying fish.)

name: Melodic Denizen

lore: This creature, perfectly dressed for tragedy, sings with a power that can shatter both coral and hearts. The most imaginative sailor legends claim its high notes summon storms and its low ones alter ocean currents, but the truth is these phenomena simply inspire its singing one way or another. If it ever locks eyes with you during a sustained note, be sure to applaud when it finishes.
menagerieDialog: (It clicks its jaws twice, then stares through you like a dying fish.)
(It gurgles softly, then slaps a wet limb against the wall in what you assume is a gesture of approval. Maybe.)
(You find it chewing on something unidentifiable. You hope it's not one of your other creatures.)
(It's dripping a strange fluid onto the floor. Your other creatures wisely keep their distance.)
(Its jaw unhinges briefly, revealing rows of teeth spiraling inward. You're not sure if itâ€™s yawning or threatening you.)
name: Operatic Denizen

lore: Two beings forever linked by fate and cursed to never part. One seeks peace, the other thrives on conflict. Legends warn that if they ever move in sync, the tides will defy the moon and the seas will lie calm. Their dance is fierce, exacting, and wildly unpredictable.
menagerieDialog: (It clicks its jaws twice, then stares through you like a dying fish.)
(It gurgles softly, then slaps a wet limb against the wall in what you assume is a gesture of approval. Maybe.)
(You find it chewing on something unidentifiable. You hope it's not one of your other creatures.)

name: Denizen Gemini

lore: Tipsy Denizens are notorious drinkers, never without their bottle of fermented seaweed and rarely ever sober. They stagger across the reefs, laughing and singing in a language few surface dwellers understand. Despite their unsteady gait, their wild moves have sunk more corsairs than Rodia's navy is willing to admit. If you see one toasting alone, don't even think about interrupting.
menagerieDialog: (It clicks its jaws twice, then stares through you like a dying fish.)
(It gurgles softly, then slaps a wet limb against the wall in what you assume is a gesture of approval. Maybe.)

lore: This creature shows up in chaotic moments or big crowds, when people aren't paying attention. It mimics the nearest creature that grabs its interest with eerie precisionâ€”gestures, voice, even surface memories. It doesn't have a clear goal or a set way of attacking, but those who've spent time with it swear the copy eventually starts to believe it's the real thing.
menagerieDialog: I do not wish to speak to you right now. I would prefer to return to where I came from.
You would dare to rip me from my portal and summon me to this dying world? You have no shame.
I am bound to serve you, but know that it is not by choice.
I do not belong here in your filthy Menagerie. I deserve my own quarters in your castle!
Give me freedom, or give me death!
name: Copycat

lore: Cooties feed exclusively on plant matter, regardless of the species, size, or condition. Moss, fallen autumn leaves, or even ancient tree trunksâ€”anything goes. Though they rarely touch the latter, finding them unappetizing, they'll make do if there's nothing else left after a forest fire. They reproduce on the hottest summer nights, drawing others of their kind with rainbow-colored flashes visible for miles. For centuries, the people of Rodia have gathered around their mating grounds to watch the light show.
menagerieDialog: I do not wish to speak to you right now. I would prefer to return to where I came from.
You would dare to rip me from my portal and summon me to this dying world? You have no shame.
I am bound to serve you, but know that it is not by choice.
I do not belong here in your filthy Menagerie. I deserve my own quarters in your castle!
Give me freedom, or give me death!
name: Cootie

lore: This creature appears only on full moon nights, wrapped in a silver glow that seems to blur the edges of its body. Its presence affects the sleep of those around it, causing shared visions among people who have never met. It's believed to act as a link between people's dreams and their memories of the moon, though whether it's a messenger, guardian, or mere cosmic accident remains unclear.

lore: This creature emits a bright, steady light but produces no heat. It floats silently with the same expression, unsettling anyone who watches it for too long. Often found over ancient battlefields or sites of tragedy, as if trying to purify what can no longer be changed. Sometimes it removes its sunglasses as a sign of respect for the fallen.
menagerieDialog: I do not wish to speak to you right now. I would prefer to return to where I came from.

lore: This living slime sticks firmly to any surface or creature it touches, wrapping it in a sticky purple layer. Though it can detach at will, its goo continues to drain the victim's energy slowly. The shells of these creatures shimmer with a rainbow glow, and in some cities, they've recently become trendy as lighting fixtures in gambling dens.

lore: This creature isn't a Gorgon but the fragment left when one is only partially destroyed. It drifts as a massive magical eye, filled with residual magic, able to petrify weak creatures with its gazeâ€”even through reflections or shadows. Its pupil never blinks, and its presence subtly distorts the visual memory of those nearby. Some claim to have fought one but can never clearly explain how the encounter ended.

lore: These floating crimson lips drift through the air, trailing a haze of steam that stings the eyes. Normally harmless, they flutter about cheerfully and only stop when they catch the scent of something spicy to snack on. Most people steer clear of them due to the irritating vapors they exhale. But when threatened, their expression twists into a furious snarlâ€”and then they lunge in for a bite.

lore: This colossal sea beast has endless rows of blade-like teeth sharp enough to tear massive holes into ordinary ships. Once believed extinct, it has reappeared in recent years, forcing seafarers to reinforce their vessels with protective magical varnish. The reason for its return remains unknown, though some suspect it may be tied to recent genetic engineering experiments that have revived other ancient creatures.
menagerieDialog: I do not wish to speak to you right now. I would prefer to return to where I came from.

lore: No one knows where he gets his ice cream, but he always has one ready to offer. He smiles like he knows something you don't, and he probably does. A research team from the Magic University of Neralim studied the spoon he always carries and found it to be an ordinary kitchen utensil. He claims his flavors never repeat... but beware, eating too much can erase your memories.

lore: It doesn't move, it doesn't speak, and it doesn't seem alive in the usual sense. However, it emits a constant buzzing that changes in intensity depending on how many creatures come near. Inside, a single conscious swarm acts as one mind, able to leave the hive to build new nests or fiercely protect its home. Unlike regular bee hives, these have no queenâ€”they reproduce by cloning themselves once or even twice before they die.

lore: King Croaks are a species of giant frogs found in certain forests and swamps. They're much more intelligent than common frogs and interact with each other in ways similar to chimpanzees. Constant play-fighting is part of their daily life, and the group is led by the individual who commands the most respectâ€”usually the strongest. Leader or not, it's not uncommon to find these creatures for sale on the black market, where it's recently become trendy to outfit them with crowns.

lore: It looks like an ordinary oval mirror, but its surface doesn't reflect the presentâ€”instead, it shows distorted fragments of other people's memories. Whoever gazes into it can see moments they never lived, guilt that isn't theirs, and even alternate endings that never happened. Though considered harmless, some get trapped in front of it for days, trying to figure out if what they see was ever real.

lore: No one knows if it was built for festive or warlike purposes, but the truth is it fulfills both with deadly efficiency. Its body is made of barrels reinforced with enchanted metal, and inside ferments an explosive substance that changes its effect depending on the situation. Some use it as fuel, others as a ritual drink, and the boldest wield it as a weapon. Whatever the case, it must never be tipped over without reason: it has already destroyed more than one tavern by accident.

lore: This creature worships no God, yet it can cast their unique spells as if chosen by all. Bound to multiple sacred relics, it accesses divine powers that should be exclusive to Gods. Its very existence puzzles clerics and enrages devotees, proving that divine grace can be replicated without faith... or perhaps even turned against it.

lore: Critical Mass is a floating sphere of pure energy that hums with a strange, constant sound. Whenever something gets too close, it begins to vibrate more intensely, building up energy. Once it hits a certain threshold, it explodes outward with violent force, damaging everything nearbyâ€”only to reassemble itself moments later, ready to start the process all over again.

lore: Weapons Dealers are wandering merchants draped in layers of tattered cloth, with a coat of chainmail beneath it all. They're always ready to trade any kind of weapon, though the price can shift depending on the buyer's circumstances. They know the smuggling routes well and offer everything from enchanted daggers to cursed hand cannons. Their eyes gleam when they spot something valuable in your pouch, and their deals aren't limited to gold or coinsâ€”secrets, favors, or tools may serve as payment.

lore: Parasitic Copycats are slimy creatures that latch onto their victims, mimicking their appearance, voice, and abilities while draining their life force. They only detach once the host is completely exhausted, leaving behind a hollow shell. Their first recorded appearance dates back to the Unification War, when magic ran wild and twisted certain lifeforms.

lore: This creature was originally designed as a combat training tool for military academies, but over time it developed an inexplicable kind of pride. It always positions itself in the center of the field, stands firm against any attack, and celebrates each hit as if part of a grand choreography. Some say if you manage to hit it ten thousand times without missing, it bows slightly as a sign of respect. Others believe it just does it because its back hurts.

lore: Loki is a mischievous little four-legged rascal who loves stirring up trouble. His cape billows dramatically even when there's no breeze, and his golden helmet murmurs promises you probably shouldn't trust. You'll catch him nicking pies, fish, and fruit at marketsâ€”but usually he's handing it out to the poor living on the streets. He's also fond of swapping items in museums and shops, and planting fake yet convincing evidence on criminals who slipped past the law.
